value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">36</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">As the habit of reading becomes universal, readers split off</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">into different classes. There is the 
            <choice>
              <sic>specilaised</sic>
              <corr>specialised</corr>
            </choice> reader, who</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">attaches himself to certain aspects of the 
            <choice>
              <sic>rpinted</sic>
              <corr>printed</corr>
            </choice> word.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Again there is the very large class of perfectly literate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">people who strip many miles of print yearly from paper</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">yet never read a word. Finally 
            <choice>
              <sic>ere</sic>
              <corr>there</corr>
            </choice> is the reader like</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="typewriter" place="above">who, like</add> Lady <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aclif" key="Clifford, Ann">
            <choice>
              <sic>AnnnClifford</sic>
              <corr>Ann Clifford</corr>
            </choice></rs> read excellent <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">
              <choice>
                <sic>C aucers</sic>
                <corr>Chaucer's</corr>
              </choice></rs> book when they</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are in trouble <quote source="#" rend="inline">"and a little part of his beauteous spirit</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">infuses itself in me."</quote> Hexmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmx And the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">curious faculty --the 
            <choice>
              <sic>pow r</sic>
              <corr>power</corr>
            </choice> to make places and houses,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">men and women and 
            <choice>
              <sic>theit</sic>
              <corr>their</corr>
            </choice> thoughts and emotions 
            <choice>
              <sic>vivible</sic>
              <corr>visible</corr>
            </choice> on</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the printed page is a xxxx always changing. The <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cine" key="Cinema">cinema</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">now 
            <choice>
              <sic>develping</sic>
              <corr>developing</corr>
            </choice> his eyes; the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-broa" key="Broadcast">Broadcast</rs> is 
            <choice>
              <sic>develpoing</sic>
              <corr>developing</corr>
            </choice> his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ear. His importance can be gauged by the fact</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that when his attention is distracted, in times of public</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">crisis, the writer exclaims: I can write no more.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But the presence of the reader was felt even</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">while the play was still on 
            <choice>
              <sic>th</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> stage. It was for him that</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rbur">Burton</rs> composed that 
            <choice>
              <sic>extraodinary</sic>
              <corr>extraordinary</corr>
            </choice> composition the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-anat" key="Anatomy of Melancholy">Anatomy</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-anat">of Melancholy</rs>. It is there that the reader makes his</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">first appearance, for it is there that we find the writer</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">completely conscious of 
            <choice>
              <sic>is</sic>
              <corr>his</corr>
            </choice> relation with the reader.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xxx and He reveals himself. I am a 
            <choice>
              <sic>bachelor</sic>
              <corr>batchelor</corr>
            </choice>I am neither</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rich nor poor. I am a tumbler over of other mens books.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">I live in college rooms. I am a spectator not an actor.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There is 
            <choice>
              <sic>n</sic>
              <corr>no</corr>
            </choice> playhouse audience forcing him to embody his</l>
